poem:
To the Daughters

In the house—  
late summer crosses   
the threshold, silence  
crowded with care.

Hands, weary with  
the weight of unseen vows,  
mend wounds untouched   
by time or state.

Love, not policy,  
fills the void—  
a sigh in the dark,  
a whisper of  
duty's endless echo.
